linkTarget.anchoringText: After loading the actual data on the pressure and flow rate, a model study curve is created, which must be combined with all registered filtration regimes in the reservoir. An example of such well-test is shown in Fig.1

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Example of draw-down test, registered by the gage on the ESP.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example of draw-down test, registered by the gage on the ESP.

linkTarget.anchoringText: For this, it is necessary to know the design bottomhole pressure at which the well will work, and also to take into account the influence of the environment (the presence of a number of producing and injection wells). An example of such a forecast is shown in Fig. 2

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Example of the forecast of the well production rate based on the results of the well-test using the Decline Analyze method.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example of the forecast of the well production rate based on the results of the well-test using the Decline Analyze method.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Also, using the Decline-Analyze method, it is possible to predict the flow rate and the pressure in the well just commissioned. The following is an example of predicting the pressure and flow rate in a horizontal well XX6G. The first step is to interpret and adjust the model to the actual data. Figures 3 and 4 show the results of a similar configuration for a horizontal well in Cartesian and double logarithmic coordinates.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Results of combining the initial data with the model curve for the well XX6G

formatted-caption.caption-text: Results of combining the initial data with the model curve for the well XX6G

linkTarget.anchoringText: Also, using the Decline-Analyze method, it is possible to predict the flow rate and the pressure in the well just commissioned. The following is an example of predicting the pressure and flow rate in a horizontal well XX6G. The first step is to interpret and adjust the model to the actual data. Figures 3 and 4 show the results of a similar configuration for a horizontal well in Cartesian and double logarithmic coordinates.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Log-Log analysis graph of the draw-down test of the horizontal well XX6G

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-Log analysis graph of the draw-down test of the horizontal well XX6G

linkTarget.anchoringText: The obtained production decline allowed calculating the forecast of the future well production, both taking into account the current downhole pressure decline trend, and for the pressure drop increase with the production stimulation by a decrease in bottomhole pressure to 70 kgf / cm2 (Fig.5 as the graphs show, with pressure drop increase, daily well production drops to the level without intensification after ~2 months. This is due to a sharper fall of reservoir pressure, in the case of production stimulation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Liquid rate and pressure forecast in the started well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Liquid rate and pressure forecast in the started well

linkTarget.anchoringText: With daily monitoring of well production, a sharp drop in well production was detected, almost 2 times. This drop in production can be attributed to the shutdown of a neighboring injection well. With the help of the technique of Decline Analyze, two variants of the development of events were predicted: in case of further idling of the injection well and in case of its launch into operation (Fig. 6).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Forecasting the flow rate and pressure in the production well, depending on the various workings of the wells of the pressure maintains system (a - without intensification of the pressure maintains system, b - in the case of optimization of the pressure maintains system)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Forecasting the flow rate and pressure in the production well, depending on the various workings of the wells of the pressure maintains system (a - without intensification of the pressure maintains system, b - in the case of optimization of the pressure maintains system)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: without intensification of the pressure maintains system
in the case of optimization of the pressure maintains system

linkTarget.anchoringText: The layout of the wells in this section is shown in Fig. 7
The data from the gages along the well of XX9G (Fig.8) were compared with the theoretical model of a multifracture horizontal well, which produce from a homogeneous reservoir.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Results of combining the initial data and the model curve.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Results of combining the initial data and the model curve.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The initial coefficient of productivity in combination with all hydrodynamic parameters is determined in the interpretation of the well start cycle (Fig. 9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Log-Log analysis graph of the draw-down test of the horizontal well XX9G

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-Log analysis graph of the draw-down test of the horizontal well XX9G

linkTarget.anchoringText: When comparing the results of the interpretation, it can be seen that after flooding, water cut, transmissibility and the skin factor increased. In all likelihood, this is due to the fact that with the growth of depression in the well opened the cross-flow. Based on the results of such monitoring, the PLT in the vertical part of the well was recommended to localize the cross-flow and consider the possibility of carrying out the workover. PLT was performed. When it was interpreted by the anomaly of the thermal flowmeter, casing leakage was detected (Fig. 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Results of PLT in the vertical sati of the wellbore XX9G

formatted-caption.caption-text: Results of PLT in the vertical sati of the wellbore XX9G

linkTarget.anchoringText: However, such monitoring allows not only to identify candidate wells for RIR, but also to select wells for repeated fracturing, allowing for a significant increase in production [2].Consider the example of well XX75. Figure 11 shows the interpretation of the well after the first and second fracturing.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Results of well testing for re-fracturing wells XX75. A) - an overview graph of the test, b) - a characteristic graph in log-log coordinates. Red – well-test after the first fracturing, blue - after the second.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Results of well testing for re-fracturing wells XX75. A) - an overview graph of the test, b) - a characteristic graph in log-log coordinates. Red – well-test after the first fracturing, blue - after the second.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: an overview graph of the test
a characteristic graph in log-log coordinates. Red – well-test after the first fracturing, blue - after the second

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 12 shows the location of the wells in the analyzed area. Before the study was the task to determine the current trend of changes in reservoir pressure and determine the further development of the system of pressure maintenance at the site of the field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Location of wells in the analyzed area

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location of wells in the analyzed area

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: History of the wells of the analyzed area. Well 1 Well 2 Well 3 Well 4 Well 5 Well 6

formatted-caption.caption-text: History of the wells of the analyzed area. Well 1 Well 2 Well 3 Well 4 Well 5 Well 6

linkTarget.anchoringText: With the help of MWD technology and Sofoil’s PolyGon software algorithms, a bottomhole pressure curve was obtained in hypothetical operation of a well in the absence of an environment when solving the multi-well deconvolution equation system (Fig. 14a).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Analysis of well 1 (central for the section in question). a) - an overview of the change in bottomhole pressure (blue-actual data, red - alignment result, green - well pressure dynamics in the absence of influence of surrounding wells); b) transient response; c) the position of the radial flow regime in interpreting the transient response

formatted-caption.caption-text: Analysis of well 1 (central for the section in question). a) - an overview of the change in bottomhole pressure (blue-actual data, red - alignment result, green - well pressure dynamics in the absence of influence of surrounding wells); b) transient response; c) the position of the radial flow regime in interpreting the transient response

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: an overview of the change in bottomhole pressure (blue-actual data, red - alignment result, green - well pressure dynamics in the absence of influence of surrounding wells)
the position of the radial flow regime in interpreting the transient response

linkTarget.anchoringText: When solving the multi-well deconvolution equation system, it is possible to obtain cross-well transient characteristics. Interpretation of these transient characteristics using the interference test algorithm allows obtaining a transmissibility in the interval between the well under investigation and affecting it nearby well. Convolution of cross-bore transient characteristics makes it possible to obtain curves that characterize the amplitude of the influence of surrounding wells in given pressure units on the investigated one throughout its operation. An example of such data is shown in Fig. 15.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Example of cross-bore transient characteristics in log-log coordinates a) interval between wells 1 and 3, b) the interval between wells 1 and 4

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example of cross-bore transient characteristics in log-log coordinates a) interval between wells 1 and 3, b) the interval between wells 1 and 4

linkTarget.anchoringText: The dynamics of reservoir pressure obtained in the analyzed area is shown in Fig. 16.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Dynamics of reservoir pressure based on interpretation results (blue - actual data on bottomhole pressure, red - result of overlap, green - dynamics of reservoir pressure of the well).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dynamics of reservoir pressure based on interpretation results (blue - actual data on bottomhole pressure, red - result of overlap, green - dynamics of reservoir pressure of the well).

linkTarget.anchoringText: At the same time, a quantitative determination of the contribution of each of the surrounding wells to the dynamics of the pressure variation of the section in question was performed. The results are shown in Fig. 17 Influence amplitude lines are the result of a convolution of cross-bore transient characteristics, it is possible by their behavior to determine both the total and current amplitude of the influence of one of the environment wells on the investigated one.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Dynamics of bottomhole pressure of well 1 and pressure dynamics from each of the surrounding wells influencing its operation as a result of interpretation (numbers near the lines - numbers of surrounding wells.) Well 3 is indicated twice - during extraction and injection).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dynamics of bottomhole pressure of well 1 and pressure dynamics from each of the surrounding wells influencing its operation as a result of interpretation (numbers near the lines - numbers of surrounding wells.) Well 3 is indicated twice - during extraction and injection).
